content.text:
The data in the table below was from a Framingham study. In this study, 1045 men aged 33-49 years were followed for 10 years to observe the development of coronary heart disease. The serum cholesterol levels of the 1045 subjects were measured at baseline enrolment, and they were divided into 5 groups according to their serum cholesterol levels. The number of cases of coronary heart disease in each of these groups after 10 years of follow-up was shown in the table below.<image 1> If the serum cholesterol level 114-193 mg/dl group is used as the reference group, the RR of the serum cholesterol level 231-255 mg/dl group is.

A. 5.48
B. 6.98
C. 12.96
D. 15.95

To determine the relative risk (RR) of having coronary heart disease in the serum cholesterol level 231-255 mg/dl group compared to the reference group (serum cholesterol level 114-193 mg/dl), we need to use the formula for calculating the RR:

\[ \text{RR} = \frac{\text{Incidence rate of disease in the higher cholesterol group}}{\text{Incidence rate of disease in the lower cholesterol group}} \]

Given that the incidence rate of coronary heart disease in the 231-255 mg/dl group is 26 cases and the incidence rate in the 114-193 mg/dl group is 2 cases, we can calculate the RR as follows:

\[ \text{RR} = \frac{26}{2} = 13 \]

Therefore, the RR of having coronary heart disease in the serum cholesterol level 231-255 mg/dl group compared to the reference group (114-193 mg/dl) is 13.

The correct answer is:

C. 12.96
Now, output the final answer and nothing else:
